Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE - DAY

Dialogues.Line: We are shown the open doors to the two offices. Toby is in the left, and Sam is in the right. They yell so they can hear each other.
Is it gonna rain?
No.
It looks like it's gonna rain.
It's overcast.
Isn't that usually what it is before it rains?
Yes.
But in this case?
It's not gonna rain till later today.
If it rains, please remember to change the opening line.
It's not gonna rain till one, maybe two o'clock.
Yeah, but if you're wrong, you gotta change the opening line! Sam goes into TOBY'S OFFICE.

I'm not getting this from morning drive-time radio, Toby. I'm getting this from First Lieutenant Emily Lowenbrau of the U.S. Coast Guard, who would not let me down 'cause she has a very really...a very comforting voice.

Okay, here's my thing. If you're wrong, if the coast guard is wrong, the remarks open with 'As I look out over this magnificent vista.' If the event gets moved indoors, he will no longer be looking out over a vista of any kind.
Do you honestly think he can't change that on his feet? Do you honestly think the President doesn't know where he is when he's giving a speech?
This isn't a major policy address, Sam. This is five minutes in front of the United Organization of Trout Fishermen. I'm saying if it gets moved inside.

I got this from the U.S. Coast Guard. I got this from the National Weather Service. They use satellites. They use technology. Behind Toby, outside the window, lightning flashes. Thunder claps. It started to rain.
This is the same satellite technology we use to detect intercontinental ballistic missiles, right?
Yeah.
All right then. Toby and Sam head out the office. They meet C.J. outside.
We should move the thing inside.
Sam says it's probably not gonna rain till later.
Have either of you heard anything about a piece of paper that's going around?
What piece of paper? They all walk out into the HALLWAY.
I don't know. At the Gaggle, Dave Trillin asked what I knew about a piece of paper that's going around. Maybe you used from the campaign.
I haven't heard anything.
Me either.
Let's find out.
That's good advice, Toby. Cutting into a CORRIDOR. They meet Leo.
We're in the second floor auditorium in the O.E.O.B.
And they're moving people inside?
People are there. They moved them twenty minutes ago.
Why?
The weather report said it was gonna rain.
It did?
Yeah.
Is it possible First Lieutenant Emily Lowenbrau is yanking me around?
Where's the President?
He's already over there. They walk out to the LOBBY.
How's his mood today?
We had breakfast. He seemed very upbeat, very energetic, very optimistic about the day.
How long do you think do you suppose that's gonna last? Leo, Sam, Toby and C.J. head out of the White House into the rain.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OLD EXECUTIVE OFFICE BUILDING - DAY
Scenes.Description: President Bartlet, Mrs. Landingham, Charlie, Nancy are riding the escalator to the second floor of the O.E.O.B. Secret Service Agents surround them.

Dialogues.Line: Can we get this Godforsaken event over with so I can get back to presiding over a civilization gone to hell in a handcart?
Nice talk for a President.
Leave me alone. They reach the second floor.
You know what this is, don't you sir?
What what is?
Your mood, sir.
There's nothing wrong with my mood.
It's your diet.
Would you get off me with that?
You're not getting enough roughage in your diet. You know I'm right about that.
I know I'd like to beat you senseless with a head of cabbage. I know that for damn sure.
Once again, you display an immaturity about vegetables and I think is not at all Presidential.
Charlie, does anyone have my remarks?
Sam's bringing them, Mr. President.
Is Toby on his way?
Yes sir.
C.J.?
Yes sir.
Why aren't they here right now?
They didn't know that it was raining, sir.

Nothing like surrounding yourself with the best and the brightest, Charlie. Cutting through the hallway, they pass an entrance. The President meets with the rest of his staff: Toby, C.J., Sam and Leo. They just came from the pouring rain. Everyone continues to walk.
Good morning, sir.
Good morning, Mr. President.
Good morning, sir.
Hello.
How are you, sir?
You didn't know it was raining?
To our credit sir, we knew it was raining once it started to rain.
Okay.
Here are your remarks, sir.
A couple of things, uh, who am I gonna be talking to now?
The United Organization of Trout Fishermen.
No, seriously now.
Sir?
Give me the damn speech.
There's some very nice anecdotes there about trout fishing.
Have I ever been trout fishing?
Probably not.
Okay.
[comes from behind] Good morning, Mr. President.
What's going on Josh?
The C.V.O.'s gonna revise its outyear projections, two commissioners resigned from the F.E.C. this morning, and the N.G.A. endorsed trigger locks.
How much?
The projections?
Yeah.
Uh, maybe 200 billion?
Hang on. Everyone stops walking near the entrance to the auditorium.
Two F.E.C. commissioners resigned?
Yes sir.
There are two seats open in the F.E.C.?
Yeah.
Sir?
This is interesting.
Sir, this is not the world's best time to go off on a flight of idealistic-
Leo, two seats just opened up in the Federal Election Commission.
And the Senate Leadership will fill them.
I'm saying, what if this time we say we want our guys?
We won't win.
Yeah, but we can dangle our feet in the water.
It's not a good idea, sir.
Josh-
Mr. President, you're thinking about changing the nature of democracy.
I'm talking about dangling our feet in the water. Josh, get Leo two candidates who back aggressive campaign finance reform.
Sir, I-I got to stand with Leo on this. I think that-
I'm not saying jump off the boat, Josh. I'm saying dangle our feet.
Yes, sir. Nancy is waiting in front of the entrance to the auditorium.
Mr. President?
Yes. Somebody?
The United Organization of Trout Fishermen.
Thank you. Bartlet and his staff head for the auditorium.
You gonna concentrate on this now, or is your head gonna be in changing the nature of democracy?
No, I'm definitely gonna be thinking about the trout fishermen, Leo, 'cause that's where my focus should be.
You were in a better mood an hour ago, Mr. President.
I was in a better mood a year ago, Leo.
[to Leo and Josh] Does anybody know anything about a piece of paper that's been going around?
What piece of paper?
I don't know.
C.J., are you taller than you usually are?
Yes sir. I'm my usual height.
Okay.
Here we go.
Couldn't pick a trout out of a police lineup, by the way.
Focus. Bartlet goes inside the auditorium with Nancy, Charlie and C.J. The rest of the staff stays outside.
Ladies and Gentlemen, the President of the United States!
Two Federal Election seats open on the same day?
You can dream all you want Josh, but you're dead in the water, it's never gonna happen.
That's what I thought too, but after your little pep talk just now... We hear Bartlet inside the auditorium. The staff stands watch by the door.
Thank you. Thank you very much. It's good to see you. Thank you. Toby and Sam just realized something.
Sam?
Damn it!
What?
I forgot to do something.
As I look out over this magnificent vista... Toby looks away in frustration as Sam slams his notebook.

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES.
FADE IN: INT. HALLWAY - DAY

Dialogues.Line: How does the F.E.C. work?
Six commissioners are appointed for a six-year term.
Overlaps.
Two seats come up every two years.
And two commissioners just resigned?
At the same time.
How many times has that happened?
Including this time?
Yeah.
Once.
So the President has the opportunity to back the F.E.C. without people and make immeasurable impact on campaign finance reform?
Yes.
Well, do it baby!
There's a couple of roadblocks.
What?
Whenever a vacancy comes up, the party leadership of both sides... [pause] Did you just call me 'baby' back there?
Yeah.

Okay. Uh, when a vacancy comes up, it's up to the President to fill it, but the party leadership on both sides always, always, always dictates to the President who he's gonna appoint. One Republican. One Democrat. Whoever the leadership says. That's how you keep the peace.
But you're gonna change all that, right?
No, but I'm gonna spend the rest of the week trying.
That's not the right spirit, Josh. You're trying to change the nature of democracy.
You're right. I'm gonna need a bagel. [goes into his office]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. BRIEFING ROOM - DAY

Dialogues.Line: The Easter egg hunt and the Easter egg roll are two different things. The theme of this year's event is 'Learning is delightful and delicious,' as, by the way, am I. The reporters laugh.

The collection, which is gonna be on display on the east colonnade to the White House, features real chicken eggs decorated by artists from each of the 50 states and the district. And the activities are coordinated by the American Egg Board. And I've hung with some of the cats from the American Egg Board, and they are party people. Thank you. That's it for this afternoon. As the reporters get ready to leave, C.J. leaves the podium and goes to Steve.
Steve?
Yeah?
You got a second?
Sure.
What have you heard about a piece of paper that's out there?
Same thing you've heard.
What's that?
There's a piece of paper out there.
That's it?
Yeah.
If you hear anything more, you'll tell me first?
If I find anything more, I'll tell my editor first.
I keep forgetting you don't work for me.
Yes, you do.
C.J.?
See ya.
Bye. Steve leaves. C.J. faces Mandy.
Mandy, there's a buzz in the room. Something about a piece-
Yeah.
Do you know anything about it?
I know everything about it.
What do you mean?
I wrote it.
What is it we're uh...
I wrote a memo when I was working for Russell outlining strategies- Mandy quickly looks away as Katie comes from behind C.J.
Excuse me, C.J.?
Katie, they're in the blue room.
Thanks. [leaves]

When I was working for Russell, I wrote a memo outlining the weaknesses and vulnerabilities of the Bartlet administration and mapping out a strategy to defeat him for renomination. [pause] C.J. this is embarrassing and a little mortifying, but you got to remember how pissed off I was at you guys.
You worked for us for a year and a half, and you work for us again now...
...And in between, you wrote a playbook on how to beat us?
I was working for Russell, and the whole idea is to-
I need to see a copy of it right now!
C.J.? C.J. storms out of the briefing room and slams the door.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Leo is in front of his computer.

Dialogues.Line: [calls] Margaret!
[comes in] Yes?
I can't e-mail.
They're working on the problem.
What's the problem?
My friend, Lynette, from the President's Council on Physical Fitness, you remember her?
[irritated] No.
She's the one where you say, 'Who's that?' And I say, 'That's my friend, Lynette, from the President's Council on Physical Fitness.'
Hey.
Oh, hey Josh.

Anyway, she sent me an e-mail about the actual calorie count in the raisin muffin they're serving in the mess. I forwarded the e-mail to several hundred assistants and secretaries in O.E.O.B. and in the West Wing, and that was fine. But Jolene Millman, who works in political liaison, then hit reply, which apparently-

Oh Margaret! Margaret! I'm sorry. I'm gonna have to...I hung in there as long as I could, but you long since passed the point when I stopped caring. If you're curious, it was right around raisin muffin.
I'll leave you two alone.
And fix the e-mail.
Yes. [leaves]
So, who'd you come up with?
John Bacon and Patricia Calhoun.
Oh, I know John Bacon. Who's the other?
Patty Calhoun's the director of the Roe Institute for Economic Policy Studies at the Heritage Foundation. She worked in the White House O.M.B. under two Republican Presidents.
And she favors campaign finance overhaul?
Aggressive overhaul.
Then the leadership's gonna hate them both.
What do you want me to do?
Meet with the top guys in the leadership offices.
You want me to meet with the leadership?
Absolutely not. I want you to meet their guys, and I want you to do it outside the building. Do it over a meal.
Leo, the President can't think we're gonna get anywhere with this, can he?
Hmmm?
The President doesn't think we're gonna get anywhere with this, can he?
No.
Okay.
What happened with e-mail?
Oh, I don't know. It has something to do with the President's Council on Physical Fitness.
Okay. Josh leaves. Leo looks swiftly.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Josh comes out of Leo's office. Sam and Toby see him.

Dialogues.Line: Hey.
Who'd you come up with?
John Bacon and Patty Calhoun.
Not in a million years.
Tell me something else I should know. What are you doing?
It's our turn with the boys.
Knock 'em dead.
Hey, listen.
Yeah?
You want me to do the talking when we get in there?
Why?

Just asking. Toby opens the door to THE ROOSEVELT ROOM. Toby and Sam meet with several majors and congressmen in the room. MAJOR TATE, MAJOR THOMPSON, and two Congressmen, KEN and MIKE, are seated around the table.

Good morning. Good morning. We all know each other. Why don't we sit down? We've been conducting meetings with various senior staff on the D.O.D., N.S.C. and House and Senate Armed Services. We feel a little hamstrung because of the policy inherited regarding gays and lesbians in the military. And we'd like as much reform input as possible before making a recommendation to the President.
Toby, can I interrupt you for a moment?
Sure.
What do you imagine'd be the consequence of your recommendation to the President?
Well, actually, it'll be Sam's recommendation to the President. It's on his desk, and I'm just helping out.
Sam, what do you imagine'd be the consequence?
Major, bearing in mind that the President seldom, if ever, listens to my recommendation, I'd imagine the consequence to be little.
I would imagine it to be very little, Sam.

Congressman, the commander-in-chief orders that gays can serve openly in the military. That's the way it's gonna be, and anybody who chooses to disobey that order can stand court marshal under the uniform code and military justice.

The President can order the joint chiefs and the chiefs can give all the orders they want. It takes an act of Congress to amend the uniform code. And the uniform code makes sodomy a crime. That's the end of the story.
I guess it's gonna be a pretty short meeting.
Yeah.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. comes out of the briefing room. Donna follows.

Dialogues.Line: C.J.?
Yeah?
There will be 25,000 wooden eggs in addition to the 7,500 other eggs.
What are the other eggs made out of?
Ah... the other eggs are...
They're actually eggs.
Yeah. Mandy's in your office.
What is Josh doing?
F.E.C. commissioners.
Would you tell him when he has a free moment I'd like to see him?
Yeah. Donna goes the other way. C.J. meets Carol in her desk.
Carol, 25,000 wooden eggs.
In addition to the 7,500 eggs that are...
They're just regular eggs.
Okay. C.J.'S OFFICE. C.J. sees Mandy, carrying an envelope.
Is that it?
Yeah.
Who has it?
I don't know.
But somebody does.
Yeah.
Okay. I'm gonna read it now.
Should I...?
Go back to your office, and don't answer any questions.
You'll...call me when you're done reading?
I'd count on it. Mandy leaves. C.J. starts reading.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. CAPITOL HILL ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Josh is meeting with the STEVE ONORATO, and other aides from the Leadership office. They are in the middle of a meal.

Dialogues.Line: Soft money contributions render the 1974 Campaign Reform Act toothless. Soft money contributions, which were ostensibly designed for party-building, whatever that might mean, do nothing but eviscerate any meaningful election controls. We are, by definition, corrupt.
I wouldn't say that.

I know you wouldn't, Steve. This money isn't coming in in 5's and 10's and 20's. It's coming in in denominations of 100, 200, 500 thousand dollars. It's coming from special interests. It's coming from special interests whose interests aren't the same as those who don't have a half a million bucks lying around, and it's not going to party-building. It's going to issue ads. It's going to candidates.
Yeah. It's called free speech, Josh.

If the insurance company wants to buy ad time from 64 major markets, they are free to do so. If the airplane manufacturing industry wants to back a candidate, they are free to shout from the rooftops. If big tobacco wants to wave a sign or put a bumper sticker on their cars, they are free to do so. That's free speech. Money isn't speech.
I like it when Josh comes here once in a while to teach us a lesson we so richly deserve.
I came here as a courtesy, Jerry. I came at the request of Leo McGarry. The President is strong considering... John Branford Bacon and Patty Calhoun to fill in the two seats.
I'm pretty sure we've already got our two guys, don't we?
Yes.
It's Grant Kalen.
Grant Kalen and Joe Barkley.
Two people who oppose any campaign finance reform. Well...
I thought you like Kalen, Josh. He got a lot of democrats elected in Indiana.
He raised a lot of money in Indiana. And Joe Barkley says that people are allowed to spend whatever they want in politics.

Yeah. So does the Supreme Court, by the way. Uh, Josh, look, we can't have this meeting every time the President wakes up in the morning and decides to make the world better. The party leadership's gonna choose a Republican. The party leadership's gonna choose a Democrat. That's the way it's always been. That's the way it's gonna be. That's the way it is.
Really?
Yes.
The President makes appointments to the Federal Election Commission.

And the Senate confirms them. And I'm speaking from the majority leader. Embarrass us like this, and we will give the same back to you tenfold. Every piece of legislation the White House wants off the table will make a sudden appearance.
Yeah. Steve's talking our greatest hits, Josh. 5-4-1, school prayer, Family Support Act, Entertainment Decency Act.
English as the national language.
English as the national language will be first up. That's gonna be our leadoff hitter.
Wouldn't it be easier to just not confirm our nominees?
Oh, we're gonna do that too.
Are you saying that in addition to voting down our nominees, there's gonna be political retribution for having nominated them in the first place?

Yes. You know why? Because you know if you do this, you're gonna lose, and we're gonna look bad winning. I also got to say that I reject the suggestion that the best way to maintain free speech is by having government regulate it.
[quietly] Reject whatever you want.
I-I didn't hear that.

I said reject whatever you want! You know, four hours ago, this was a fool's errand for me, and the President knew it. This was a test balloon. This was a 'just out of curiosity let's see what would happen if' meeting, but you've managed to get me on board.
Steve, we got a caucus.
We got to go. They all leave the room. Josh sits still.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: Mrs. Landingham comes out of her office. Charlie follows.

Dialogues.Line: Mrs. Landingham.
I'm going to lunch, Charlie.
Speaking of lunch.
Yeah?
The President's not too wild about his.
What's the nature of his dissatisfaction?
He said it's made almost entirely of vegetables.
It's a salad, Charlie.
The President'd prefer a sandwich. He says roast beef would be fine. Pastrami, sliced steak...
Charlie, tell the President he will eat his salad. If he doesn't like it, he knows where to put his salad.
Well, I don't think I will tell the President that, Mrs. Landingham, but I appreciate your help.
You bet.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE ROOSEVELT ROOM - DAY

Dialogues.Line: It ain't broke, don' fix it, Sam.
Officer...
'Don't Ask, Don't Tell' works.
No, it doesn't.
Yes, it does.
Do you like to know how much it doesn't? Eleven hundred and forty-five were discharged from being gay in 1998.
That's a record.

It's a 92% increase since 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell' was implemented. 414 Air Force discharges--the highest in two decades. 271 of them during basic training at Lackland Air Force Base. 271 during basic training.
Major, what the hell is going on at Lackland Air Force Base?
I don't like your sense of humor.
I get that a lot.
[comes in] Excuse me. I'm sorry. I need Toby.
Yeah. [to Sam] Come here a sec. Toby and Sam go to the door. Toby whispers to Sam.
You're doing good. [to C.J.] What? Toby goes out into the CORRIDOR.
I know what the piece of paper is.
What is it?
It's a recon-and-strategy memo that Mandy wrote when she was working for Russell.
Strategy to do what?
Beat us in three years.
Did you read it?
Yeah.
Is it bad?
Yeah.
Let's go to my office. C.J. and Toby walk away.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. NORTHWEST LOBBY - DAY
Scenes.Description: Josh comes in the White House. Donna is standing in the middle waiting for him.

Dialogues.Line: How'd it go?
[surprised] How do you know to be standing here?
I see you at the window.
You don't have a window.
You have a window.
What are you doing in my office when I'm not there?
Looking for you at the window.
Okay. They walk off.
How'd it go?
It went fine.
Just fine?
Yeah.
You don't want to say anything more than that?
I don't, Donna, and the way that you know that I don't, is that I'm not.
But this is our special time together.
I'm really not in the mood to mess around.
Okay.
I need you to get me prepped on something.
What?
English as the national language.
Why?
Might come up.
Why?
Because...it doesn't matter. Because if we do a thing with the F.E.C., opponents will put English as the national language on the table.
Are we for it or against it?
Donna...
I mean we're not in favor of making another language the official language, are we?
Donna!
Like Dutch of something.
Donna, didn't I just say that I can't mess around?
Okay.
Yes.
Bullet points?
Yeah.
Give me thirty minutes?
Thank you. [goes into his office]
Oh, and Toby said to come by as soon as you got back.
Toby?
Yeah. Josh hurries out.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. TOBY'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. watches as Toby reads. Ginger knocks and pokes her head in.

Dialogues.Line: Toby.
I'm not taking any calls right now, Ginger.
It's-
I'll call him back. Ginger closes the door and walks back to her desk.
[reads] 'The reality of the Bartlet White House is a flood of mistakes. An agenda hopelessly stalled and lacking a coherent strategy. An administration plagued by indecision...' Someone knocks.
Ginger!
[comes in and closes the door] What's going on?
Mandy wrote an instruction manual for Russell, and it's out there somewhere.
Where?
I don't know yet.
How bad is it?
Well, she takes the three of us to town. We don't look like rocket scientists. But, then again, we're not rocket scientists.
Who is it bad for?
The President... Leo. The President and Leo.
We don't know who has this?
I'm talking to everybody in the room.
Do it quietly.
And quickly. Whose paper will it be in tomorrow? We have to know right away.
Yeah. C.J. leaves. Josh sits beside Toby.
Our second year doesn't seem to be going a whole lot better than our first, does it?
No.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. MARGARET'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Toby comes in. Leo's office door is closed. He approaches Margaret, who's in front of her computer.

Dialogues.Line: Margaret, does he have a minute?
He's finishing up with the chairman.
They almost done?
Yeah.
I'll wait.
You having problems with your e-mail?
Yeah.

Technical support says the pipeline's been flooded. Apparently it happened when I forwarded an e-mail to several people, and one of them tried to reply. Everyone's e-mail box is clogged with replies, which are now, automatically and constantly bounding back and forth at subatomic speed... [pause] I passed the where you're interested, haven't I?
Yeah. Leo's door opens. Out comes Admiral Fitzwallace and another officer.
Thank you, Fitz.
Thank you. Hey Toby.
Good afternoon admiral.
Toby, you here to see me?
Yeah.
Fitz, the President's gonna want to know is the Philippines redundant, that's all.
It is redundant. That's the beauty of it.
Well, you're gonna have to convince the President of its beauty.
Yeah. I will.
If you say so.
[to Toby] Say, who are those guys across the hall?
They're meeting with Sam on gays in the military.
Why?
Sam's trying to put together a coherent position.
When he comes up with one, let me know, will ya?
Yes, sir. By the way, there may be a major security breach with the White House computers.
White House computers aren't secure.
Well... that explains that. Margaret looks as Fitzwallace leaves. Toby goes into LEO'S OFFICE. Leo walks behind his desk.
He wants to put A1/M1s in Manila.
The President's gonna say it's redundant.
Yeah.
How much does it cost?
Not much. Twenty billion.
So...there's gonna be a thing.
About what?
Mandy wrote an opposition research memo for Russell, and somebody's got it.
Who?
C.J.'s finding out.
Well, it's politics, Toby. She was playing for the other guys.
Yeah... There's some observations the President's not gonna be wild about.
I move him to the middle?
The sense is that his instinct is to be aggressive, and you take him to safe ground.
Okay.
Leo...
Don't worry about it.
Hey, look...
Don't worry about it.
Want to see a copy?
No.
Okay... Okay. [looks earnestly at Leo]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. CORRIDOR - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh is walking. Donna comes from behind. She gives him a piece of paper.

Dialogues.Line: Josh?
Yeah?
Six pages on English as the national language.
Is it good?
I gave you some good stuff on James Madison and the-
James Madison?
And the Teriman resort-
I didn't ask for a damn social studies paper. I-I-
[stops walking] Don't snap at me Josh.
Donna?
Look at the memo. I gave you what you asked for. Don't snap at me. [starts walking] What's wrong with everyone today? It's been all day. Is it Mandy's memo?
No.
Why is everyone walking around like they know they already lost?
I wasn't snapping at you. I just, I-I didn't realize that you also gave me the stuff I asked for. I thought it was just...you know, I thought you just gave me James Madison.
Well, look at the James Madison. It's gonna help you.
Thanks. JOSH'S OFFICE. Josh walks inside. Mandy is waiting for him.
Hi.
Hi.
How is James Madison gonna help you?
I really don't know.
I meant that-
The President wants to put two reformers on the F.E.C. Onorato says they'll retaliate by opening up English as the national language.
The President's not gonna look good fighting against that one.
I've been working here 14 months, Mandy. Tell me what else I should know.
You should know that the President is not gonna look good fighting against that one.
Mandy...
You take an opposition to flag-burning amendment, school prayer, and gays in the military. You pile on no to English as the national language, and they will paint a picture.
I understand, Mandy.
Fine. I'm just saying that it's my job to tell you that.
You know, today, isn't really the best day for you to tell me what your job is.
I wrote an op memo, Josh. You and I have written 20 of them.
You never heard of a burn bag?
They got it off my hard disk.
You know who has it?
No.
Then there's not much you can do for us today.
You shouldn't let the President get into a debate on English as the national-
Mandy, it's not gonna happen. Don't worry about it. It's not gonna happen. The President's not gonna nominate who he wants in the F.E.C.
Why not?
'Cause it's not what we do.
All right. I'll leave you alone.
Thanks. Mandy leaves. Donna comes in.
It's everyone that's feeling this way today?
Yeah.
Oh, okay. Thanks.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE ROOSEVELT ROOM - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: Hang on!
I'm saying-
Hang on. A lot of those cases-
This report, by the way-
We know the report.
I'm saying-
We can read. We know the report.
We know the report. A lot of the cases you're talking about is the gays being discharged, came from voluntary statements-

And a lot of these are not voluntary statements, not by any definition given by any civilian court in this country. It is not a voluntary statement when it's given to a psychotherapist, as in the case of former Marine corporal David Blessing. It is not a voluntary statement when it's made into a personal diary, as in the case of former West Point cadet Nicole Garrison. It is not when it's made after being asked, as in the case of master chief officer Diane Kelli. And it is not when it is coerced out of a service member through fear...through intimidation, through death threats, in terms of criminal prosecution, as in the case of former Air Force Major Bob Kiddis, former Marine gunnery sergeant Kevin Keys, and four sailors aboard the U.S.S. Essex.
Sam, you take care of your guys; we'll take care of ours.
You're not taking care of your guys. Your guys are out looking for jobs.
Those weren't our guys. Admiral Fitzwallace enters.
Oh my God.
Attention! The officers in the room swiftly stand straight.
Good afternoon, Sam.
Mr. Chairman.
Congressman.
How do you do admiral?
Good to meet you again, Ken. [to Mike] We haven't met.
Mike Satchel.
From Oregon?
Yes, sir.
Percy Fitzwallace.
It's an honor to meet you, admiral.
I imagine it would be. Yes.
Uh, Major Tate, Major Thompson, this is Chairman Fitzwallace.
They're not gonna speak to me until I speak to them, Sam. They're pretty well-trained. [to Tate and Thompson] Stand easy, fellas. [sees the snack on the table] Is this Danish for everybody?
Oh. Yes sir.
[to Tate and Thompson] We're discussing gays in the military, huh?
Yes sir.
What do you think? No response.
I said what do you think?
Sir, we're here to help the White House form a possible-
I know. I'm asking you what you think.
Sir, we're not prejudiced toward homosexuals.
You just don't want to see them serving in the Armed Forces?
No sir, I don't.
'Cause they oppose a threat to unit discipline and cohesion.
Yes sir.
That's what I think too. I also think the military wasn't designed to be an instrument of social change.
Yes sir.

The problem with that is that what they were saying to me 50 years ago. Blacks shouldn't serve with Whites. It would disrupt the unit. You know what? It did disrupt the unit. The unit got over it. The unit changed. I'm an admiral in the U.S. Navy and chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff...Beat that with a stick. [to Ken] We'll see you, Ken. [leaves]
Excuse me. Sam leaves and goes into the HALLWAY. He tries to catch up with Fitzwallace.
Mr. Chairman... Just, thanks for stopping in.
You're not gonna get anywhere.
The President just wanted some exploratory meetings.
Yeah. Fitzwallace walks away. Sam goes back to the room.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. PRESS ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: C.J. walks in. She sees Danny typing.

Dialogues.Line: Danny.
Hey.
I was hoping to find you here. I wanted to ask you-
Hang on.
I wanted to ask you-
Hang on. C.J. waits impatiently behind Danny.
Danny, is it the Magna Carta or-?
I'm trying to finish a thought here.
Go ahead.
[pretends to think] I'm finished.
Okay. You've heard there's a piece of paper out there, right?
Yeah.
You know what it is?
It's a strategy memo for Russell?
That's right. [pause] You got to know, I don't want exploiting our friendship in any way, and I certainly don't like taking advantage of any feelings beyond friendship you might have for me.
Right. You have them for me too.
I don't.
Okay.
I need to be ready for this...Do you know who has it?
Yes.
Who has it?
I do.
You have it?
Yeah.
And you're gonna write about it?
Sure.
Why?
Look-
Why?
'Cause it's news, C.J.
It's not news.
It is.
It's not news just because it's entertaining, Danny.

It's news 'cause a media director of a successful Presidential campaign wrote a memo to a leader of a President's party describing his weaknesses. Well, there are other people in the President's party. A lot of them buy my newspaper, and I think they'd like to know what Mandy thinks, and I don't think that's at all out of line.
Mandy wasn't working for the President at the time she wrote this memo-

I don't care if she's working for Bask'n Robbins when she wrote this memo. She's a key player in the Democratic Party, and she says the President is staggeringly vulnerable. And that may not be good news for you, C.J., but it's news. [pause] At this morning's briefing, you asked us to write about Easter eggs so I wouldn't be-
Fine.
C.J.?
We'll have a comment for you at the end of the day. C.J. walks off. Danny follows.
[yells] None of this is our fault, C.J.!
None of what is your fault?

Mandy thought it was a pretty accurate analysis, and you know it. You knew she was working for Russell, and you knew why. You knew she had to have written the memo. Why wasn't it the first thing you asked for when you hired her? 'Mandy, tell us everything you think we're doing wrong.' 'Cause you knew what she was gonna say. You knew she was right. You knew there was nothing you could do about it. [pause] You guys are stuck in the mud, around here, and none of it is the fault of the press. I know you're frustrated. But it ain't nothing compared to the frustration of the people who voted for you, so don't come in here and question my...'We'll have a comment for you by the end of the day'? When I want the White House to comment on a story of mine, I'll ask for it, C.J. [calms down] I got to do this. I have to do this work.
Okay. C.J. walks out the door. Danny goes back to his computer.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. ROOSEVELT ROOM - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: I'd like to go on record by saying-
Congressman.
No. I'd like to go on record-
There is no record.

I'd like to go on record saying that I have no objection to what somebody does in the privacy of their own home. But when we're talking about schools, when we're talking about the boy scouts, when we're talking about an army barracks-

You know, Ken. There's something I'd always wanted to ask you. What does being gay mean you can't keep your hands to yourself? Over what kind of gentlemanly pride of the Armed Forces willing to lay claim the restraint in that area? You want me to get the file on sexual harassment on the D.O.D.? Do you want me to ask these guys about Tailok?
I've had enough of this.
And I've had more than enough of this!

Sam, don't ask, don't tell, don't pursue is the law. It's federal law, and it takes an act of Congress to change it. If the President were serious about changing it, he'd be serious about changing it. He would not send you in here with me. He would not send you in here with two relatively junior D.O.D. staffers. He'd call his staff together, he'd say, 'I want a resolution in the House. I want 50 high-profile co-sponsors. I want a deal, and I want it now.' Has the President done that?
The President's veracity on this-
Has the President done that, Sam?
No.
Okay then... Is this meeting anything more than a waste of time?
No.
Okay then. Everyone leaves. Sam sits still.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. MARGARET'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Toby, while waiting for Leo, is talking to Margaret.

Dialogues.Line: I.T. support is now accusing me of being a hacker. They're accusing me of spamming or smurfing. They asked me if I was running a Trojan horse. I said no, I...I was simply informing the others that the calorie count in the raisin muffin was wrong. And it is, Toby. You don't believe me...You should take one of those muffins and you know, take it down to the lab.
I'll do that.
Will you?
Get me a muffin. Be careful not to handle it yourself. You want to use gloves. Slip it to me in a plastic bag. I'll send it off to the lab.
You're mocking me now, aren't you?
Yes. Leo's office door opens.
Come in. Toby comes in LEO'S OFFICE. Leo walks to sit.
Margaret thinks the F.B.I.'s gonna bust in here any minute.
Yeah.
I got my second bit of bad news for you today, Leo.
You got new numbers?
Yeah.
How bad is it?
CNN/USA Today puts our job approval at 42%.
We dropped five points?
Yeah.
In a week?
His unfavorables are higher than his favorables for the first time. Fifty-four percent of the country is likely to vote for a Republican Congressional candidate in November.
We dropped five points in a week?
Yeah.
We didn't do anything last week.
I'll say.
Toby, when you start thinking about jumping ship, you'll let me know, right?
One victory in a year, Leo.
Toby-
Mendoza. We got Mendoza on the Court.
This President was elected with 48% of the vote, Toby.
Yeah, but he was elected.
Without a mandate. The majority of people in the country voted for somebody else.
I don't care, Leo. He was elected. He was sworn in. I was standing ten feet from the chief justice.
I'm saying it's not the easiest circumstance on...
Who the hell said it would be easy?
... One victory in a year isn't so bad!

One victory in a year stinks in a life of an administration. But it's not the ones we lose that bother me, Leo. It's the ones we don't suit up for! [pause] And I'm not too crazy about you questioning my loyalty just then. Someone knocks.
Yeah?
[comes in] Hey.
Oh. Hey C.J.
The President's reading Mandy's memo. I just gave it to him.
I wish you hadn't done that, C.J.
Why?
It's just gonna piss him off.
It's gonna be in the newspapers tomorrow.
Did you find out who has it?
Danny.
And he's writing it?
Yeah. It should run right next to the new polling numbers. Josh and Sam come in from the other door.
How did we drop five points in a week?
It happened. Let's move on.

What I think is, the Senate will confirm Bacon and Calhoun. They'll have to 'cause their credentials are too good, and the voters want campaign reform. As a punishment, they'll roll out a legislative agenda designed to force the President to come down on the unpopular side of everything. For instance, they'll bring out English as the national language. I believe-
We're not gonna let it on the table.
I think we shouldn't be afraid-
Josh!
Leo, I think we shouldn't be afraid to get into it on English as the-
He's not gonna let it on the table.
Then we'll live with their candidates for the F.E.C.
As we always have.
Yes.
[to Sam] What about you?
My meeting?
Yeah.
It was the same meeting we've been having for... [beat] It was fine. Everyone's faces are covered with sadness. Charlie knocks and walks in from the Oval Office.
Yeah?
I'm sorry to interrupt. [points to the Oval Office]
Yeah. Leo stands and goes into THE OVAL OFFICE. Bartlet is seated in a chair, with memo in his hand. Leo comes in. Charlie closes the door and stays there.
Who's got this?
Danny Concannon.
Why am I just finding out about this now?
We spent most of the day learning about it ourselves.
I really did wake up energized this morning.
I know.
I never go to bed that way.
I know.
Just once, in this job, I'd like to end a day feeling as good as I did when the day started. [pause] Are you bothered by this?
The memo?
Yeah.
Yes.
We've heard it all before, Leo. You drive me to political safe ground. It's not true.
I know it's not true.
Good. [heads for his desk]
You drive me there.
[turns] What the hell did you say?
And you know it too.
Leo?
We're stuck in neutral because that's where you tell me to stay.
You're wrong.
No. I'm not, sir.
You want to do this now?
Sir?
You came to my house, Leo.
Mr. President?
You came to my house, and you said, 'Jed, let's run for President.' I said, 'Why?' And you said, 'So that you can open your mouth and say what you think!' Where'd that part go, Leo?
You tell me, Mr. President. I don't see a shortage of cameras or microphones around here. What the hell were you waiting for?
Look...
Everything you do...
This morning-
Everything you do says: 'For God's sakes, Leo. I don't want to be a one-term President.'
Did I not say put our guys on the F.E.C.?
No sir. You did not do that.
Leo!
You said -- No! You said, let's dangle our feet in the water of whatever the hell it is we dangle our feet in, when we want to make it look like we're trying without pissing too many people off!
You're writing a fascinating version of history, my friend.
Oh, take a look at Mandy's memo, Mr. President, and you'll read a fascinating version of it.
You brought me in on teachers. You brought me in on capital gains. You brought me in on China. And you brought me in on guns.

Brought you in from where? You've never been out there on guns. You've never been out there on teachers. You dangle your feet, and I'm the hall monitor around here. It's my job to make sure nobody runs too fast or goes off too far. I tell Josh to go to the Hill on campaign finance, he knows nothing's gonna come out of it.
That's crap.
Sam can't get real on Don't Ask, Don't Tell because you're not gonna be there, and every guy sitting across the room from him knows that.
Leo, if I ever told you to get aggressive about campaign finance or gays in the military, you would tell me, 'Don't run too fast or go to far.'
If you ever told me to get aggressive about anything, I'd say I serve at the pleasure of the President. [pause] But we'll never know, sir, because I don't think you're ever gonna say it.
I have said it, and nothing's every happened!

You want to see me orchestrate this right now? You want to see me mobilize these people? These people who would walk into fire if you told them to. These people who showed up to lead. These people who showed up to fight. [points at Charlie] That guy gets death threats because he's black and he dates your daughter. He was warned: 'Do not show up to this place. You're life will be in danger.' He said, 'To hell with that, I'm going anyway.' You said, 'No.' Prudent, or not prudent, this 21 year old for 600 dollars a week says, 'I'm going where I want to because a man stands up.' [pause] Everyone's waiting for you. I don't know how much longer.
I don't want to feel like this anymore.
You don't have to.
I don't want to go to sleep like this.
You don't have to.
I want to speak.
Say it out loud. Say it to me.
This is more important than reelection. I want to speak now.
Say it again.
This is more important than reelection. I want to speak now.
Now we're in business! Leo goes to the table and picks up a pen and writes on a pad.
What's happening?
We got our asses kicked in the first quarter, and it's time we move up the mat.
Yes!
Say it.
This is more important than reelection. I want to speak now.
[while writing] I'm gonna talk to the staff. I'm gonna take them off the leash.
You have a strategy for all this?
I have the beginnings of one.
What is it?

I'm gonna try that out for a little while. Leo puts the pad on the desk in front of the President. It reads, 'LET BARTLET BE BARTLET.' The President looks at it and back to Leo as his chief of staff goes back into-- LEO'S OFFICE. The staff are still inside. Leo takes off his jacket and leans on his desk.
Listen up. Our ground game isn't working. If we want to walk into walls, I'd want us running into them full speed.
What are you saying?
Well, you can start by telling the Hill the President has named his nominees for the
Josh looks surprised.

And we're gonna lose some of these battles, and we might even lose the White House, but we're not gonna be threatened by issues. We're gonna put them front and center. We're gonna raise the level of public debate in this country, and let that be our legacy. [turns to Josh] That sound all right to you, Josh?
I serve at the pleasure of the President of the United States.
[to C.J.] Yeah?
I serve at the pleasure of the President. Leo turns to Sam.
I serve at the pleasure of President Bartlet.
Toby?
I serve at the pleasure of the President. Everyone turns their frowns into big smiles.
Good. Leo turns to his desk and gets a clipboard. He turns back to his staff.

Then let's get in the game! Toby, Sam, Josh and C.J. exit. Leo walks to a table to get a pen. He looks at the open door to the Oval Office. He sees Bartlet, who has been standing there watching. Bartlet nods at him. Leo smiles back before Bartlet walks back to his desk.

Scenes.Scene Heading: DISSOLVE TO: END TITLES.
